conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction \(\mu\) between the sheets of the books.
The books are divided into \(n\) equal parts.
When book \(B\) is pulled out, it experiences frictional forces from each part of book \(A\).

premise: Consider the situation where book \(B\) is divided into \(n\) parts.
conclusion: Each part of book \(B\) will experience a frictional force due to the corresponding part of book \(A\).

premise: For \(n\) divisions: Each part of book \(B\) has a weight of \(\frac{5 \text{ N}}{n}\).
conclusion: The normal force \(N\) on each part of book \(B\) due to the corresponding part of book \(A\) is \(\frac{5 \text{ N}}{n}\).

premise: The frictional force \(f\) between each pair of parts is given by: \( f = \mu N = \mu \left(\frac{5 \text{ N}}{n}\right) \)
When book \(B\) is pulled out, the total frictional force \(F_f\) acting on book \(B\) is the sum of the frictional forces from all \(n\) parts of book \(A\).
conclusion: The total frictional force is \( F_f = n \times \mu \left(\frac{5 \text{ N}}{n}\right) = 5\mu \text{ N} \).

premise: From the table, when \(n = 4\), the force \(F\) required to pull out book \(B\) is \(46.5 \text{ N}\).
conclusion: This force must be equal to the total frictional force: \( F = 46.5 \text{ N} = 5\mu \text{ N} \).
